notes: Sixth generation midsize car (1988-1997). GM W-body platform. Convertible available 1990-1995. Data sourced from Wikipedia Oldsmobile Cutlass Supreme article, January 2025 revision.
Rebadged Chevrolet Malibu (1997-1999). GM N-body platform. Replaced Cutlass Supreme. Data sourced from Wikipedia Oldsmobile Cutlass article, January 2025 revision.
Ninth generation full-size sedan (1992-1999). GM H-body platform. Royale and LSS trims. Data sourced from Wikipedia Oldsmobile 88 article, January 2025 revision.
Eleventh generation flagship (1991-1996). GM C-body platform. Discontinued 1996. Data sourced from Wikipedia Oldsmobile 98 article, January 2025 revision.
First generation flagship (1995-2003). GM G-body platform. Cadillac Northstar V8 derivative. Data sourced from Wikipedia Oldsmobile Aurora article, January 2025 revision.
Midsize sedan (1998-2002). GM W-body platform. Replaced Cutlass Supreme. Data sourced from Wikipedia Oldsmobile Intrigue article, January 2025 revision.
Compact car (1999-2004). GM N-body platform. Replaced Achieva. Final Oldsmobile produced. Data sourced from Wikipedia Oldsmobile Alero article, January 2025 revision.
Second generation minivan (1990-2004). GM U-body platform. Shared with Pontiac Trans Sport/Chevy Venture. Data sourced from Wikipedia Oldsmobile Silhouette article, January 2025 revision.
First generation luxury SUV (1991-2004). Rebadged Chevy Blazer/GMC Jimmy. SmartTrak AWD system. Data sourced from Wikipedia Oldsmobile Bravada article, January 2025 revision.
Compact car (1992-1998). GM N-body platform. Replaced Calais. Quad 4 engine available. Data sourced from Wikipedia Oldsmobile Achieva article, January 2025 revision.
Fourth generation personal luxury coupe (1986-1992). GM E-body platform. Final generation. Data sourced from Wikipedia Oldsmobile Toronado article, January 2025 revision.
Full-size wagon (1971-1992). GM B-body platform. Final Oldsmobile RWD vehicle. Data sourced from Wikipedia Oldsmobile Custom Cruiser article, January 2025 revision.
